content: Met with an old mentor for coffee. Discussed my career path and got some invaluable advice on how to tailor my resume for quant trading firms.
Spent the last few days refining my risk management protocols. I've backtested my new strategies against historical data. The results are promising, but real-world application is next.
Just uploaded a new video on my YouTube channel discussing advanced ML models in market analysis. Got some great feedback and a few new subscribers.
Had a second interview with a quant trading firm. They loved my approach to risk management, but they're looking for more experience with international markets.
Connected with a former colleague who now works in London. We're planning a virtual session to discuss international market insights.
Attended a local trading meetup. Shared my insights on ML models for market prediction, got some constructive criticism, and made new connections.
The meetup led to an opportunity to collaborate on an AI-driven trading algorithm. We're in the early stages, but it's exciting to work on something so cutting-edge.
Spent the last few days diving deeper into the theoretical aspects of ML. Realized how much I still have to learn. The journey is both humbling and exhilarating.
Had a setback. One of the firms I applied to rejected my application. It's a reminder that rejection is part of the process, but it stings.
Took the rejection as motivation. Revamped my LinkedIn profile, highlighting my recent work on risk management and ML models.
Received an email from another quant firm interested in discussing my application further. They were impressed by my online content.
The virtual session with my London colleague was insightful. We discussed the nuances of trading in different time zones and currency fluctuations.
Our AI trading algorithm project is gaining traction. We're now in the phase of optimizing for real-time data integration.
Had an epiphany while working late last night: the best strategies are those that balance innovation with practicality. Time to refine my approach.
